data.title: Cry 'Havoc' (1943)
data.meta_description: The Army nurses on Bataan need help badly, but when it arrives, it sure isn't what they expected. A motley crew, including a Southern belle, a waitress, and a stripper, show up. Many conflicts arise among these women who are thrown together in what is a desperate and ultimately hopeless situation.
data.text:
“They’re Americans Cap, they believe in a happy ending.”

It takes a while for this to kick in and for the first half hour I thought it might be a real chore. Clunky dialogue, cheap sets and Ella Raines really getting the short end of the stick in this female dominated ensemble piece. Imagine M*A*S*H from the nurses tents.

We follow a group of new and very green volunteer replacement nurses and aides arriving at a WW2 Philippines field hospital. Short on supplies, food, medicine these scrappy dames survive on pride, street smarts and a quick wit.

This gets progressively darker and knowing the real life circumstances one gets to wonder how these young women are going to get outta…

Mark Antony: “raging for revenge, with Ate (goddess of mischief and ruin) by his side come hot from hell, shall in these confines with a Monarch's voice cry 'Havoc!' and let slip the dogs of war.

"Havoc" is a military order permitting the seizure of spoils after a victory: rape, pillage, and plunder.

The "dogs of war" are the political and societal restraints against war that operate during times of peace.

This film was initially released about a year after the Battle of Bataan and the Bataan Death March (but this event was not made public until January 1944 so the film was widely released February 1944) so it would have been perhaps even more stirring than it is today.…

The context of this film is certainly interesting, even for a WWII film. In April, 1942, a very large American force surrendered to the Japanese at the end of the Battle of Bataan in the Philippines, thus precipitating the Bataan Death March, a Japanese war crime. The play that formed the basis for this film was written in September, 1942, and it tells the story from another angle, that of a group of American nurses in the area. However, the Death March had not been disclosed to the American public until January, 1944, after this movie was made and released, and as such, it focuses just on the doomed, lost cause that resulted in a massive surrender.
